description.narrative: The program will help the government of Guyana to improve solid waste management services in Georgetown. It includes the institutional development of responsible offices and environmental and sanitation education activities.

activity-description.narrative: A training workshop on hazardous and healthcare waste was organized for the Environmental Protection Agency, which was involved in the environmental impact assessment prior to the construction of the Haags Bosch landfill site.
Construction of the main access road to the Haags Bosch landfill site. Additional roads within the site are being built and widened to accommodate the increase flow of garbage disposal trucks.
Each landfill cell at Haags Bosh is 3 meters deep, 16 acres in size and has a lifetime of 7 to 10 years.

In 2006, the Ministry of Health completed a study to determine best practices and other priorities for the disposal of certain types of medical waste material. As such, measures are being taken to have certain types of medical waste being disposed at the Haags Bosh Sanitary Landfill.
In 2010, the Le Repentir landfill site was decommissioned and by 2011, fully closed. Landfill cells have been covered with 3 meters of clay and includes methane pipes which allows for ventilation.
Institutional Legal Framework study completed and approved
Once fully operational, the Haags Bosch Landfill site will serve the capital city, Georgetown and 15 Neighborhood Democratic Councils in Region 4.
The Diamond/Grove landfill has been partially decommissioned and closed. Complete closure will take place in 2013.
The Neighborhood Democratic Councils (NDCs) received training in data collection and costing for sustainability.

The waste pickers group which previously worked at the Le Repentir Landfill Site have been organized and relocated to the Haags Bosh Sanitary Landfill. Facilities complete with storage lockers, canteen, washrooms and toilets have been constructed to support the work of the group.
With a team of engineers and professionals, the Ministry of Local Government and Regional Development plays a key role in the coordination of solid waste management in Region 4.
